page.title: 10A SHORT HISTORY OF CULROSS 2
page.content: In the sixth century the monks of Culross gave refuge to the pregnant mother of Kentigern later to be called St. Mungo, patron saint of Glasgow.The saint was born in Culross and educated by St.Serf. The monks were the first miners in Culross. Hand-in-glove with mining in seaside towns went salt-panning. Inferior, very smokey coal from the mines was used in fires to evaporate salt water. Culross had fifty.It must have been very smokey! As in many Fife coastal towns trade was carried on with Scandinavia and the Low Countries.They exported coal and salt and brought back pantiles as ballast. Rich merchants not only used the pantiles but copied the designs of roofs from those countries with which they traded. Culross became rich -the "Culross chalder" became the Standard Scottish measure for weighing coal.
